awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Higher-Order Methods for Nonlinear Stochastic Structural Dynamics
awd_abstract_narration:
This Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) grant is to study the influence of real, observable dynamic loads that are randomly varying in nature (e.g. wind velocity and pressure) on structures that exhibit complex behavior. This study will enable more accurate structural modeling that will inform improved design practices for high performance structures that operate for longer service lives at lower cost. The research will be applicable to structures of all sorts where efficiency is critical and loads are highly unpredictable, ranging from civil structures to aircraft, automobiles, ships, and spacecraft. This award supports fundamental research to simulate the nature of these randomly varying loads in greater detail than has been previously possible. Leveraging these studies, the response of different classes of structures subjected to such environments will be investigated with the ultimate aim of optimizing performance. The award will also support the development of new undergraduate research modules, which will be made publicly available, designed to introduce students to careers in research and teach basic research skills that are useful beyond academia. 

Many physical phenomena are characterized by complex stochastic processes that exhibit strongly non-Gaussian and nonlinear features. This project will build new methods for characterizing and synthesizing these higher-order stochastic processes that will be used as excitation for various nonlinear structural systems. The nonlinear structural systems studied herein - including hyperelastic, elastic-plastic, and chaotic systems - are especially sensitive to the nature of the stochastic excitation and may exhibit drastically different structural behavior based on seemingly minor changes in the stochastic excitation. Currently, the sensitivity of nonlinear structural response to various features of the stochastic excitation is not well understood. This research will extensively study this sensitivity for different classes of nonlinear structural systems and develop new topology optimization model to enhance structural performance.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
This project focused on the challenge of modeling complicated physical systems whose input, loading, or excitation is random in nature and can be modeled as a random process or a random field. This occurs in many engineering contexts where the input to a system is unpredictable in time or may vary randomly over some spatial region such as wind pressures on a structure, ocean surface wave forces on a ship or offshore structure, or seismic loading of a bridge or building. We specifically showed that the methods used to model these random processes can have an important influence on predictions of the response of engineering structures and systems and therefore improved methods of random process simulation are critical for reliability, safety, and performance analysis.

The project also involved a novel educational program to instruct undergraduates in research methods and the research process, while also encouraging them to participate in undergraduate research and to view research as an important component of their career beyond college. This educational program began with the development of a new course at Johns Hopkins University and the use of that course as a research study itself through a method known as ?Teaching as Research.? In this effort, students conducted surveys before and after taking the course to measure knowledge of basic research principles, engagement with research activities, and intentions for career research aspirations. Data from these surveys were collected over five years to monitor changes in the students? knowledge, perceptions, and plans as a result of the course. The results showed that the course fostered their engagement in research, demonstrated knowledge gains, and sometimes promoted changes in their future research plans. This new material was then developed into an online course entitled ?Uncertainty and Research,? which is offered on the Coursera platform and available globally to be viewed free of charge.

Intellectual Merit: The project developed a new theory for the simulation of random processes that are encountered in a variety of fields and can be used to model the loading or excitation to engineering systems. Because the way that random processes are modeled can have a profound impact on the predicted response of an engineering system, particularly if the random process has features that are difficult to model (such as a probability distribution that is not Normal) and the system response is complicated (i.e. having response that is not linear), it is important to model them as accurately and completely as possible. The new theoretical developments in this project improve the simulation accuracy for several classes of random processes by allowing them to account for higher-order statistical features of the process. The project further developed efficient computational methods to implement this theory for computer simulations of engineering dynamical systems such as the response of structures to extreme loading like earthquakes and hurricane-level winds.

Broader Impacts: The project has had wide-ranging technical impacts. The most evident impacts are in the field of civil and structural engineering where the developed methods improvements the way we model complicated dynamical systems (structures) with random input. But the theoretical and computational methods developed are fully general and are likely to have significant impacts that range as far afield as fluid flow modeling, signal processing, and cosmology where non-Gaussian random processes are commonly encountered. The educational initiatives have had both local/individualized and global impacts. The new course added a critical new component to the curriculum at Johns Hopkins University and our data collection efforts highlighted the benefits to the students. But the impacts did not stop at Johns Hopkins. Through the Coursera course, we successfully engaged students worldwide to study research methods and practices. The course has attracted thousands of enrolled students and promoted research education to a broad and diverse audience across the world.


Last Modified: 10/02/2023
Modified by: Michael D Shields
